entry.et: Middle English, from Late Latin visualis, from Latin visus sight, from vidēre to see

def.dt: :of, relating to, or used in vision visual organs
:attained or maintained by sight visual impressions
:done or executed by sight only visual navigation
:of, relating to, or employing visual aids
:something (as a graphic) that appeals to the sight and is used for effect or illustration usually used in plural

:the relative ability of the visual organ to resolve detail that is usually expressed as the reciprocal of the minimum angular separation in minutes of two lines just resolvable as separate and that forms in the average human eye an angle of one minute
:an instructional device (as a chart, map, or model) that appeals chiefly to vision
:a sensory area of the occipital lobe of the cerebral cortex receiving afferent nerve fibers concerned with vision called also visual area
:the entire expanse of space visible at a given instant without moving the eyes called also field of vision
:the ability to recognize and understand ideas conveyed through visible actions or images (as pictures)
:a photosensitive red or purple pigment in the retinal rods of various vertebrates
